channel.title: Computer Vision on MLWhiz - Your Home for DS, ML, AI!
channel.description: Recent content in Computer Vision on MLWhiz - Your Home for DS, ML, AI!

item.title: How I Created a Dataset for Instance Segmentation from Scratch?
item.description: Recently, I was looking for a toy dataset for my new book’s chapter (you can subscribe to the updates here ) on instance segmentation. And, I really wanted to have something like the Iris Dataset for Instance Segmentation so that I would be able to explain the model without worrying about the dataset too much. But, alas, it is not always possible to get a dataset that you are looking for.

item.title: A Layman’s Introduction to GANs for Data Scientists using PyTorch
item.description: Most of us in data science has seen a lot of AI-generated people in recent times, whether it be in papers, blogs, or videos. We’ve reached a stage where it’s becoming increasingly difficult to distinguish between actual human faces and faces generated by artificial intelligence . However, with the currently available machine learning toolkits, creating these images yourself is not as difficult as you might think.

item.title: Creating my First Deep Learning + Data Science Workstation
item.description: Creating my workstation has been a dream for me, if nothing else.

item.title: Deployment could be easy — A Data Scientist’s Guide to deploy an Image detection FastAPI API using Amazon ec2
item.description: Just recently, I had written a simple tutorial on FastAPI, which was about simplifying and understanding how APIs work, and creating a simple API using the framework.

item.title: How to Create an End to End Object Detector using Yolov5
item.description: Ultralytics recently launched YOLOv5 amid controversy surrounding its name. For context, the first three versions of YOLO (You Only Look Once) were created by Joseph Redmon. Following this, Alexey Bochkovskiy created YOLOv4 on darknet, which boasted higher Average Precision (AP) and faster results than previous iterations.

item.title: A definitive guide for Setting up a Deep Learning Workstation with Ubuntu
item.description: Creating my own workstation has been a dream for me if nothing else. I knew the process involved, yet I somehow never got to it.

item.title: End to End Pipeline for setting up Multiclass Image Classification for Data Scientists
item.description: Have you ever wondered how Facebook takes care of the abusive and inappropriate images shared by some of its users? Or how Facebook’s tagging feature works? Or how Google Lens recognizes products through images?

item.title: Stop Worrying and Create your Deep Learning Server in 30 minutes
item.description: I have found myself creating a Deep Learning Machine time and time again whenever I start a new project.

item.title: Implementing Object Detection and Instance Segmentation for Data Scientists
item.description: Object Detection is a helpful tool to have in your coding repository.

item.title: Demystifying Object Detection and Instance Segmentation for Data Scientists
item.description: I like deep learning a lot but Object Detection is something that doesn’t come easily to me.

item.title: An End to End Introduction to GANs using Keras
item.description: I bet most of us have seen a lot of AI-generated people faces in recent times, be it in papers or blogs. We have reached a stage where it is becoming increasingly difficult to distinguish between actual human faces and faces that are generated by Artificial Intelligence.

item.title: A Layman guide to moving from Keras to Pytorch
item.description: Recently I started up with a competition on kaggle on text classification, and as a part of the competition, I had to somehow move to Pytorch to get deterministic results. Now I have always worked with Keras in the past and it has given me pretty good results, but somehow I got to know that the CuDNNGRU/CuDNNLSTM layers in keras are not deterministic, even after setting the seeds. So Pytorch did come to rescue. And am I glad that I moved.

item.title: Object Detection: An End to End Theoretical Perspective
item.description: We all know about the image classification problem. Given an image can you find out the class the image belongs to? We can solve any new image classification problem with ConvNets and Transfer Learning using pre-trained nets.

item.title: Today I Learned This Part 2: Pretrained Neural Networks What are they?
item.description: Deeplearning is the buzz word right now. I was working on the course for deep learning by Jeremy Howard and one thing I noticed were pretrained deep Neural Networks. In the first lesson he used the pretrained NN to predict on the Dogs vs Cats competition on Kaggle to achieve very good results.
